[[Joachim Kokate]] |clans= |headquarters= |area= [[Central African Republic]] |strength= |partof= |previous= |next= |allies= |opponents= [[Séléka]] |battles= [[Central African Republic Conflict]] | identification_symbol = | identification_symbol_label = | identification_symbol_2 = | identification_symbol_2_label = }} The '''Anti-balaka''' are a militia fighting in the [[Central African Republic]] composed primarily of Christians. However, some Church leaders have contested the exclusively Christian character of such groups{{cite web|url=http://members4.boardhost.com/acnaus/msg/1392602320.html |title= There are no Christian militias killing Muslims in the Central African Republic|publisher=Aid to the Church in Need |date= |accessdate=26 September 2016}} and the [[Tony Blair Faith Foundation]] has also pointed out the presence of [[Animism|animists]] in Anti-balaka groups{{cite web|author=Emily Mellgard |url=http://tonyblairfaithfoundation.org/religion-geopolitics/commentaries/backgrounder/what-antibalaka |title= What is the Antibalaka? |publisher=tonyblairfaithfoundation |date= |accessdate=26 September 2016}} as has journalist Andrew Katz.{{cite news|url=http://time.com/42131/anti-balaka-central-african-republic/|title=‘A Question of Humanity’: Witness to the Turning Point In Central African Republic|date=May 29, 2014|newspaper=Time|author=Andrew Katz}} They formed in the [[Central African Republic]] after the rise to power of [[Michel Djotodia]] in 2013.[http://en.apa.az/xeber_cafrica_militia_is_an_enemy_of_peace__f_206912.html C.Africa militia is an enemy of peace: French commander], apa.az, recovered 14 March 2014 There have been reports that some members of '''Anti-balaka''' groups have forcibly converted [[Muslim]]s to [[Christianity]].http://allafrica.com/stories/201507311230.html ==Terminology== Though "anti-balaka" is often translated as "antimachete", its origin is explained: {{quote|[It is] from the language of the young illiterates, who formed [[Séléka|Seleka]]’s armed opposition, and who chased the Muslim ‘anti-balles à ti laka’ (anti ti laka bullets). The term ‘laka’ in the street language of the Central African Republic means an [[AK-47]]. The anti-balakas are therefore the bearers of [[Gris-gris (talisman)|grigris]] meant to stop [[Kalashnikov rifle|Kalashnikov]] bullets.See: “La République centrafricaine: le naufrage d’un Etat, l’agonie d’une Nation», Didier Niewiadowski, Revue d’étude et de recherche sur le droit et l’administration dans les pays d’Afrique, May 2014, quoted in [https://www.globalwitness.org/reports/bloodtimber/ ''Blood Timber, How Europe Helped Fund War in the Central African Republic'' (Report), End Notes n. 21, p. 48]}} ==History== The anti-balaka militias originally formed in the 1990s as village self-defense forces and included both [[Animism|animists]] and [[Christianity|Christians]] among their members. In March 2013, President [[François Bozizé]] (a Christian) was overthrown in the [[Central African Republic Civil War (2012–present)|Central African Republic Civil War]] by a mostly-Muslim rebel coalition known as [[Séléka]]. The leader of the Séléka, [[Michel Djotodia]], then became the first Muslim president of the country.{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jfAp3fJ1ouxd_gpogscNQPKN-Cww?docId=CNG.8bc9199938545b57ad5b571a24ae95eb.121|title=Religious tensions rise in C.Africa after coup|publisher=AFP|accessdate=December 4, 2013|date=March 31, 2013}} Djotodia announced the dissolution of the Séléka in September 2013,{{cite news|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20130913-central-african-republic-djotodia-dissolves-seleka-rebel-group|title=CAR’s Djotodia dissolves Seleka rebel group|publisher=AFP|accessdate= 5 December 2013|date=13 September 2013}} but most of the militias refused to disband.{{cite news|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/nov/22/central-african-republic-verge-of-genocide|title=Unspeakable horrors in a country on the verge of genocide|publisher=AFP|accessdate=5 December 2013|date=22 November 2013}} The Séléka and the anti-balaka engaged in a cycle of increasing violence,{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-25441511|title=CAR's death toll much higher than thought, says Amnesty|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=19 December 2013|date=19 December 2013}} including reprisal attacks on individuals believed to be civilians by many.{{who|date=July 2014}} As many Christians had more settled lifestyles and many Muslims were nomadic, claims to the land were yet another dimension of the tensions.{{cite news|url=http://foreignpolicy.com/2013/11/13/we-live-and-die-here-like-animals/|title='We Live and Die Here Like Animals'|publisher=Foreign Policy|accessdate=25 November 2013|date=13 November 2013}} In November 2013, the UN warned the country was at risk of spiraling into genocide,{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-24800682|title=UN warning over Central African Republic genocide risk|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=4 December 2013|date=4 November 2013}} was "descending into complete chaos".{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-25095471|title=BBC News - Central African Republic 'descending into chaos' - UN|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=5 December 2013|date=26 November 2013}} France described the country as "...on the verge of genocide".{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2013/11/21/uk-centralafrica-france-idUKBRE9AK0WU20131121|title=France says Central African Republic on verge of genocide|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=4 December 2013|date=21 November 2013}} On 2 December 2013, anti-balaka militiamen are suspected to have killed 12 people, including children, and wounded 30 others in an attack on the mostly-Muslim Fula in [[Boali]], according to the government.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-25216351|title=Central African Republic militia 'killed' children|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=5 December 2013|date=4 December 2013}} This was amidst the [[Central African Republic conflict under the Djotodia administration]]. Early 2014 marked a turning point; hardened by war and massacres, the anti-balaka committed multiple atrocities. In 2014, Amnesty International reported several massacres committed by anti-balaka against Muslim civilians, forcing thousands of Muslims to flee the country.{{cite news|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/feb/14/muslim-convoy-central-african-republic-exodus|title=Christian threats force Muslim convoy to turn back in CAR exodus|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=17 February 2014|date=14 February 2014}}{{cite news|url=http://www.globalresearch.ca/france-and-the-militarization-of-central-africa-thousands-of-muslims-fleeing-the-central-african-republic/5369276|title=France and the Militarization of Central Africa: Thousands of Muslims Fleeing the Central African Republic|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=17 February 2014|date=14 February 2014}} ==See also== *[[Christian terrorism]] ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:2013 in the Central African Republic|Conflict]] [[Category:Rebel groups in the Central African Republic]] [[Category:Opposition to Islam in Africa]] [[Category:Persecution of Muslims]] [[Category:Christian terrorism in Africa]] [[Category:Christianity in the Central African Republic]] [[Category:Animism in Africa]]
